awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Enterprising Value: Cultural Models of Entrepreneurship in Diverse Economic Landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
Entrepreneurship is fundamentally about creating and articulating value through the identification, evaluation, and exploitation of market-based opportunities. However, research is needed to understand how this process unfolds and whether it differs cross-culturally and/or in different economic, political, and social environments, both within the United States and within the broader global economy. This study aims to ethnographically investigate how cultural schemas (i.e. shared ideas of reality and causality) of entrepreneurship differ across cultures and material environments, with specific attention to the economic, social, and cultural behaviors used in the process of value creation. 

The research will be conducted in South Africa?s Western Cape among active entrepreneurs in the Cape Town metropolitan area. This is a particularly apt research site for two reasons. First, while South Africa is one of the most robust economies on the African continent, the country still suffers from high rates of unemployment and inequality due to the lasting effects of the apartheid regime that ended only 22 years ago. The concept of "high impact entrepreneurship" to encourage new businesses to alleviate unemployment and poverty, and address South Africa?s socio-economic problems with market oriented solutions. Second, the investigators have done research in the region since 2012, and therefore have the local cultural knowledge of the region that is necessary for ethnographic work, as well as the professional contacts necessary to leverage the support needed to make significant research impact with a small amount of funding. Using participant observation and semi-structured interviews the researchers aim to discover one or more cultural models (i.e., ?schemas?) of entrepreneurship in the Cape Town metropolitan area, and to understand how these cultural schemas differ among (1) entrepreneurs who belong to different cultural groups and (2) entrepreneurs with differing levels of resources and support. Findings from this research will provide insight into how cultural models and understandings of entrepreneurship vary across different cultural environments, and how this may impact human understandings of value.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Melissa Beresford has completed research for her dissertation, “Enterprising Value: Cultural Models of Entrepreneurship in Diverse Economic Environments,” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she spent eleven months conducting ethnographic research in the business sector of Cape Town, South Africa, working among active entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, and government and NGO leaders who aim to promote entrepreneurial training and outreach. As an economic anthropologist, Beresford was interested in understanding how cultural schemas (the ways that members of a culture construct reality and understand causality) guide and shape economic practices. She chose to focus on the cultural dynamics of entrepreneurship in South Africa as the country embarks upon a national campaign to develop and promote entrepreneurship as a major avenue for addressing issues of poverty, unemployment, and income inequality (a strategy being employed by many other countries around the world). She was specifically focused on comparing the cultural schemas of entrepreneurship held by white South African entrepreneurs (who are in a dominant economic position in the country) to those of black entrepreneurs (who have only recently been allowed to own businesses due to the apartheid system that ended in 1994) to understand how access to different social, cultural, and economic resources shape cultural understandings and practices of entrepreneurship.

Beresford spent 11 months in the field, conducting participant observation and in-depth interviews in three different entrepreneurial “hubs” (communal workspaces) in Cape Town. Two of these entrepreneurial communities were in the city center with higher-resourced entrepreneurs, while the third entrepreneurial hub was in one of Cape Town’s largest townships (a residential area where black South Africans were confined to live during in the apartheid system) with lower-resourced black entrepreneurs. She established collaborative working relationships with representatives of these entrepreneurship communities early in her fieldwork, which enabled her to embed herself in the communities and collect high-quality data and develop contextual understandings of participants’ lived experiences. The data Beresford collected through her participant observation and interviews with 60 active entrepreneurs lay the foundation for an argument that she is developing about the relationship of entrepreneurship to human understandings of value. While previous generations of anthropologists saw entrepreneurs as people who created and articulated value for commodities and/or services, Beresford argues that entrepreneurs also seek to assert their own value (i.e. their importance to society) as based on their ideas rather than based on their labor (e.g. the amount of time they put into work). In this way, entrepreneurs view their businesses as vehicles for social change and re-conceptualizing the economy. The social change that they sought, however, differed between those in higher resource environments vs. those in lower resource environments given the vastly different socio-economic landscapes they inhabit.

Beresford’s research form the basis for her dissertation. To be completed in 2018, the dissertation is an important contribution to economic anthropology because it asserts how social and cultural understandings of economy shape entrepreneurial practices. In addition to this theoretical contribution, Beresford’s study has practical applications for those seeking models and strategies for economic development. Communities in South Africa and other parts of the world are seeking ways to improve livelihoods and combat inequality by bolstering entrepreneurial output. By determining how cultural models and understandings of entrepreneurship may vary across different cultural and material environments, programmatic and policy recommendations can be adjusted and improved to better suit the needs of diverse populations.


Last Modified: 10/04/2017
Modified by: Melissa Beresford
